source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: Markedly accelerated corrosion was seen at low iron + chromium concentration (≤0.14%) EMPY in steam

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: The total iron + chromium content improved the corrosion behavior in steam over the whole range studied

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: has only a small effect on 350°C corrosion where a slight minimum of the corrosion is observed at around 0.5% total iron + chromium

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: High-pressure steam tests at 500°C with this same set of materials [5] showed still larger effects of the total iron + chromium content than those seen now at 400°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: The observed effect of iron and chromium at temperatures above 400°C in steam autoclave tests may have no relevance for the uniform corrosion in power reactors, where the operation temperature is in the range of 300 to 350°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: shows the effect of the iron/chromium ratio on the post transition corrosion rate at 350°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: indicates a reduction of the corrosion rate with increasing iron to chromium ratio, especially for higher tin concentration

evidence_span: Zr-9, which had the poorest corrosion behavior of high chromium containing alloys, also exhibits the smallest precipitate size

evidence_span: The solubility of iron and chromium in alpha-zirconium is low

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: increasing the content of iron, chromium, and silicon shows a beneficial effect on uniform corrosion at 350 and 400°C in autoclave tests

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: variations in the chemical composition within the ASTM specification range result in differences of the corrosion behavior up to a factor of two

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: Chemical compositions outside the ASTM specification range offer the possibility to improve the corrosion behavior even further

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: The effect of the chemical composition on nodular corrosion is qualitatively the same as the effect on uniform corrosion for tin, iron, chromium, and carbon

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: silicon shows an opposite behavior

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk6
evidence_span: For oxygen and phosphorus there is only an influence at high temperatures (500°C)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: The uniform general corrosion behavior of Zircaloy-4 has been determined in long-term autoclave tests at 400°C

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: The cumulative effect of subsequent heat treatments in the alpha phase field after beta quenching

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: The corrosion weight gains at prolonged corrosion testing were determined and plotted as a function of the annealing parameter

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: a sharp transition from bad to good corrosion behavior occurred

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: Detailed microstructural investigations using mainly electron microscopy techniques were performed on material with known corrosion behavior both before and after corrosion tests

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: intermetallic particle size distributions were measured

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: No correlation was found between intermetallic particle sizes and the corrosion behavior

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: the matrix solute concentration is more important for the corrosion properties

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_010_chunk7
evidence_span: silicon and perhaps iron have the largest beneficial effects
